column4: hmm, i'm going to need some help with 'cp', there is a way i can have it parse a list of commands maybe? (or copy files from a list) ?
i want to copy over 9 files, with different names
but i have to do it doing: 'sudo cp -rv ....'
hmm, let me try man cp
if the list of files is in filelist.txt just do: for i in $(cat filelist.txt); do mv $i /path/to/destination; done
if there is spaces in the filename you want to put the $i after mv in quotes
not working
whats went wrong?
you can put an echo before cp to see the exact command its trying to execute
it doesn't like spaces in paths or filenames
it doesn't matter, for sees a space as a separator for the arguments
so it thinks that a new file begins there
there was some solution to it, but I can't think of it now
yes, but its still good to learn for next time
you could put __ or something instead of the spaces, and then use sed to replace the __ with a space in the mv command
do the files have the same extension or some other special pattern in them that the other files in that dir doesn't have?
well.. if you want all that starts with vid14 just do /path/to/vid14*.avi
or some other way, I'm sure there's some way to specify it
why not?
for i in in /path/to/vid14*.avi; do mv "$i" /some/other/path; done
that would work and be really cool because you can use your install with multiple computers
but only if your bios supports it
booting from usb I mean
